passages.text: Summer break is over

Data this week did little to change the backdrop ahead of more important labor market data released next week. Final private domestic demand was revised higher to \(1.9\%\) in Q2, but details still reveal strength only in specific parts of the economy, such as investment that may be related to AI. Consumption continues to slow, particularly for services. Softer services demand leaves us expecting further slowing in services inflation, particularly as home prices decline on a monthly basis. A \(0.27\%\) increase in core PCE inflation in July was as expected, with strength due to financial services unlikely to repeat. A further slowing to 45k jobs in August and the unemployment rate rising to \(4.3\%\) with upside risks next week should solidify a September rate cut, and likely a series of further cuts beyond next month.

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

Data this week did little to shift our or market expectations for the Fed to resume rate cuts in September. Next week's employment report may prove to be more consequential than CPI on September 11 for pricing in a series of rate cuts this year. We continue to expect five consecutive 25bp cuts starting in September to a 3- 3.25% policy rate.
Figure 1.2y treasury yields have been falling
Figure 2. Markets are almost fully pricing a September rate cut
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Bloomberg
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research

Core PCE inflation rose \(0.27\% MoM\) and \(2.9\% YoY\) in July as expected, with unsurprising details. Core goods prices were essentially flat on the month, weaker than core goods prices in CPI due to differences in weightings. "Supercore" services rose a strong \(0.39\%\) but with a large increase in portfolio management fees, which added \(\sim 10bp\) to overall core PCE. This strength should not repeat as increases in asset prices have slowed. As such, market- based core PCE rose a much more modest \(0.17\% MoM\) .
Figure 3. Supercore inflation was strong in July but driven by portfolio management
Figure 4. Market based core pce was softer
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, BEA
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, BEA
We still expect to see more impact of tariffs boosting goods prices in the coming months, but risks are growing that a too- weak demand backdrop means price
Figure 5. Home prices remain subdued

increases Will become gradual and smaller in magnitude. Soft consumer demand and restrictive rates make the current environment fundamentally different from the conditions that caused post- pandemic inflation.

The best example of this is in the housing market. Case Shiller home prices fell \(0.26\%\) MoM SA nationally in June, the fourth consecutive monthly decline. Weekly data on median sale prices suggest prices will remain soft on an annual basis at least for the next few months. Soft home prices should keep the trend of shelter inflation slowing throughout next year.
Figure 6. Shelter inflation should continue slowing through 2026
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, BLS, S&P
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Redfin, NAR, S&P

Revisions to Q2 GDP growth (from \(3.0\%\) to \(3.3\%\) overall) did show modestly stronger underlying details, with final private domestic demand revised from \(1.2\%\) to \(1.9\%\) . Revisions were concentrated in elements of investment, such as intellectual property products and business equipment investment. Strength in these components may partly attributed to Al- related investment.

While this trend could continue, it means upward GDP revisions do not significantly change the dynamic of slowing growth outside of these specific parts of the economy. Consumption was revised only modestly higher with services consumption still much softer this year compared to previous years. Monthly data showed real services spending continued to slow in July, rising just \(0.1\%\) MoM for the fourth consecutive month. Structures investment (business and residential) and government spending are contracting.

Of course, total quarterly GDP figures will remain heavily impacted by shifts in trade patterns this year. Imports surged again in advance- release July data, rising \(7.1\%\) MoM. Mechanically this should weigh on GDP growth in Q3 although details of trade data next week will be more important for fine tuning growth estimates. For instance, if the increase in industrial supplies imports is due to gold, this would not impact GDP. Strong imports of capital goods may boost business equipment investment.
Figure 7. Investment components were a larger boost to GDP in the second release
\(①2025\) Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, BEA
Figure 8. Imports rose in July
\(①2025\) Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Bureau of the Census

Ultimately, the health of the labor market will remain the key driver of underlying growth and consumption trends. Consumer perceptions of the labor market continued to worsen in August, with the Conference Board's labor market differential falling further from 11.0 in July to 9.7 in August.
Figure 9. More consumers are seeing jobs as hard to get
\(①2025\) Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, The Conference Board
Figure 10. "Jobs hard to get" tends to correlate closely with the unemployment rate
\(①2025\) Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, The Conference Board, BLS

In particular, the decline was due to an increase in respondents saying jobs are "hard to get", which in the past has correlated very closely with the unemployment rate. This adds to other evidence that has also historically aligned with the unemployment rate - such as continuing jobless claims and "poor sales" responses in the NFIB survey - that would suggest the unemployment rate should be higher than the current \(4.2\%\) level. We expect it will rise in August data next Friday, to \(4.3\%\) but with upside risks.
Figure 11. Rising continuing claims suggest a higher unemployment rate
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, DOL, BLS
Figure 12. Other indicators like poor small business sales also correlate with higher unemployment
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, NFIB, BLS

President Trump removed Governor Cook from the Board of Governors earlier this week. Cook filed a lawsuit to stay on the Board which is currently being considered by the courts. If Cook is granted an injunction she could stay on the Board while litigation is pending.

The main catalyst for next week will be the jobs report for August, out on Friday. We expect a soft 45k increase in nonfarm payrolls with a 60k increase in private payrolls. The slowing trend in payrolls reflects slowing immigration but also weak hiring. The unemployment rate should increase further we think to \(4.3\%\) assuming an unchanged labor force participation rate. We see risks as titled to the upside for the unemployment rate. This combination of data keeps the Fed of track to lower policy rates in coming meetings starting with September.

JOLTS job openings should increase in July but more important continue to be details like the hiring, quit and layoff rate. We will particularly be following how hiring and separations are revised after the recent large revision in payrolls.

ISMs could be a bit stronger in August but ISM Manufacturing will likely remain in contraction at 49.0 and ISM Services within the range of recent months. The employment indices will likely remain in contraction.
Figure 13. Data Release Table

Still-elevated interestrates and subdued home builder and consumer confidence have been weighing on housing market activity. Supply forboth new and existing homes has been generally increasing over the last twelve months, yet sales have not increased,pointing to soft demand as affordability remains challenging for buyers.Durable Goods Orders08/26;8:30Jul P-2.8-3-4Durables Ex Transportation1.10.40.2Cap Goods Orders Nondef ExAir1.10.40.2Total durable goods orders fell 2.8%MoM in July as very strong aircraft orders a few months ago continued to normalize.But excluding volatile transportation components, orders and shipments of core capital goods have been graduallyincreasing in recent months. This pick-up could signal stronger investment demand, with shipments of capital goodssuggesting a strong start to business equipment investment in Q3.S&P CoreLogic CS 20-CityMoM08/26;9:00Jun-0.25-0.26-0.20S&P CoreLogic CS 20-CityYoY2.141.932.2Case Shiller home prices declined for the fourth consecutive month in June on a MoM basis, with only a modest YoYincrease. A modest 0-2%YoY increase in home prices is uncommon outside of recessions and indicative of higher ratesweighing on housing demand.Conference Board ConsumerConfidence Index08/26;10:00Aug97.495.396.4The Conference Board consumer confidence index edged lower to 97.4 in August, with both the present situation andexpectations indices showing slight declines after being revised higher in July. The labor market differential, a componentof the present situation index, has fallen to its lowest level since early 2017, signaling a softening labor market as moreconsumers report jobs are hard to get.Initial jobless claims08/28;8:3023-Aug229k233k230kContinuing claims16-Aug1954k1961k1965kInitial jobless claims decreased to 229k, while continuing claims fell to 1954k. Jobless claims data continue to depict alabor market characterized by low churn, with initial claims remaining low, indicating layoffs are not rising in a concerningmanner, but also hiring remaining soft with continuing claims at higher levels relative to earlier in the year.Personal Income08/29;8:30Jul0.40.50.4Personal Spending0.50.50.5Personal spending increased by 0.5%MoM in nominal terms and 0.3%MoM in real terms, both in line with expectations.Real goods consumption increased 0.9%MoM while services consumption increased by a modest 0.1%MoM. Nominal andreal overall spending were solid this month, but the strength was driven by volatile goods categories that have beenimpacted by shifts in trade policy.PCE Price Index MoM08/29;8:30Jul0.20.20.2PCE Price Index YoY2.62.62.6Core PCE MoM0.30.30.3Core PCE YoY2.92.92.9

July PCE increased by 0.27% MoM and 2.9% YoY, in line with expectations. Core goods prices remained flat MoM, whilecore services rose by 0.36% MoM. The July PCE report showed that real services consumption growth continues to slowthis year while underlying inflationary pressures continue to look unconcernin. While services inflation picked up in July,about 0.1pp of the increase in core PCE was due to portfolio management fees that is unlikely to repeat.Advance Goods TradeBalance08/29; 8:30Jul-$103.6b-$92.1b-$89.7bAdvance Goods trade balance widened more than expected in July with imports increasing. Details in full trade data nextweek will be important to watch for GDP implications.
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research
Nonfarm Payrolls- Citi: 45k, median: 78k, prior: 73k  Private Payrolls- Citi: 60k, median: 75k, prior: 83k  Manufacturing Payrolls- Citi: - 20k, median: NA, prior: - 11k

After a substantial slowing in the pace of job growth following revisions with the July employment data, we expect this weaker trend to continue in August with just 45k jobs added. This would reflect that slowing immigration has led the "breakeven" pace of job growth to fall (likely to a bit below 100k) but also that hiring remains weak. We also expect continue net job loss in government employment, with higher uncertainty around various federal worker layoffs that may have resumed in July following a Supreme Court decision. Various changes to immigrant work status could also mean downside risks to payrolls through October.

For this past three years, a pullback in hiring has resulted in weaker employment data during the spring and summer when hiring typically picks up. Some additional pull- back in hiring this year could reflect substantial uncertainty following April tariff announcements. Details of JOLTS revisions could give some insight into whether weaker job growth was a result of high uncertainty (if there are larger downward revisions in hiring) or a result of layoffs or immigration issues (if separations are revised higher).

One frequent question we receive is if hiring and investment can pick up again later in the year as uncertainty lifts and labor supply challenges remain in some sectors due to immigration policies. There has been some increase in Indeed.com job postings through mid- August and initial jobless claims had been a bit lower than previous years in recent weeks, suggesting modestly stronger labor demand again by late July. But continuing claims rising on average suggests hiring continues to weaken and consumer perceptions of the labor market and job availability reached a new low in August. While there is not yet evidence of large layoffs, we continue to look for this as the next step in a weakening demand environment.
Figure 14. Average job growth has slowed substantially
Figure 15. Wage growth is soft in sectors possibly impacted by immigration changes, suggesting demand is also weak
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, BLS
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, BLS

Wage growth should continue slowing in a softening labor market, with a moderate \(0.3\%\) MoM increase in average hourly earnings in August and the year- on- year reading pulling back to \(3.7\%\) . This would be the slowest annual pace since mid- 2024, although still a bit stronger than a typical pre- pandemic pace. But based on details of other wage data like the Atlanta Fed's wage tracker, stickiness largely reflects a catch up of existing workers' wages while new wage pressures are very muted. As both labor supply and demand weak, the evolution of wages will be a useful test of which factor is having the larger net effect on labor markets. Recently, wage growth has been softer in sectors like manufacturing and leisure/hospitality (which has shown some of the larger effects of immigration changes). We see this as another sign that demand for workers this year is weakening more than labor supply.

We expect the unemployment rate to break above the range of the last year in August, rising to \(4.3\%\) . Our forecast assumes the labor force participation rate remains unchanged at \(62.2\%\) in August. If anything, we see risks tilted to the upside for the unemployment rate.

Of course, it is possible that the unemployment rate remains around \(4.2\%\) or may even decline, with the biggest downward risk being a further decline in labor force participation. Without the substantial decline in the labor force participation rate over the last four months, the unemployment rate would very likely be close to \(4.7 - 4.8\%\) . Earlier starting school years could suggest more of a decline in participation in August compared to in September (if this looks to be the case there could be a seasonally adjusted rebound in September).

But the biggest downside risk to participation would be slowing population growth of the immigrant work force and possible deportations. This has been a factor weighing on participation in recent months, but it is very difficult to know how much of these effects have already been captured in the monthly survey.

Despite some immigration effect, we do not think all of the decline in participation the last few months has reflected immigration issues. Rising native born unemployment and higher unemployment of new labor force entrants (which this year would not be new immigrants) suggests that demand is weakening independent of less labor supply. Larger exits of discouraged workers also exemplify how participation usually falls in weakening demand environments. Rising continuing jobless claims and worsening consumer perceptions of the labor market leave us thinking this softening in demand has worsened in August.
Figure 16. Various indicators suggest demand for workers continues to weaken
Figure 17. Payroll revisions suggest some combination of lower hires or larger separations in JOLTS revisions
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, BLS
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission.
Source: Citi Research, BLS

JOLTS job openings should increase in July to 7560k from 7437k in June, consistent with a recent uptick in high frequency data such as job postings on Indeed.com. Some recent strength in job openings could be due to immigration- related factors. Openings in the leisure/hospitality sector have been very strong in recent months, with hiring and quits in that sector also increasing substantially. This may reflect increased churn as policy changes impact the immigrant work force. But despite increased turnover in this sector, net job growth has remained soft and wages have not increased substantially, reflecting that demand has also softened.

Rather than headline openings, we continue to think details like hiring and separations are the most important aspects of the JOLTS report. In particular, the July JOLTS report could contain substantial revisions to hirings and separations over the last few months following recent payroll revisions. Much lower payroll job growth would imply some combination of more separations and less hiring. We would not be surprised to see some increase in separations, particularly "layoffs", in the leisure/hospitality sector that would reflect possible deportations or exits of immigrant workers (an involuntary separation). While hiring rates are already close to the lows of last summer, hiring in some sectors may be revised even lower, reflecting the period of substantial uncertainty after April tariff announcements. Given the continued rise in continuing jobless claims, hiring trends have likely continued to weaken.

The trade balance should widen in July to - \(79.6 billion with a large increase in goods imports and a modest decline in goods exports based on already- released advance goods trade data. This widening in the trade balance to start Q3 should weigh on Q3 GDP growth, but details of complete trade data will be more important for overall implications for growth. In particular, some elements of strong imports such as capital goods could suggest continued strength in business equipment investment in Q3. Details may also reveal any renewed front- loading of

imports ahead of tariff delays. We also expect a large share of the import rebound reflects renewed imports from China, as transit time implies shipments of goods from late May and June could arrive by July. Details will also be important for fine tuning estimates of the impact of trade on GDP. For instance, if a large increase in industrial supplies imports entirely reflects gold imports ahead of tariffs (possibly from countries like Switzerland), this would imply a much smaller drag on Q3 GDP from surging imports.
Figure 18. Imports rebounded in July
Figure 19. Construction of manufacturing facilities has been falling slowly
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Bureau of the Census
© 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, Bureau of the Census

Construction spending has declined for 9 of the last 10 months and we expect weakness to continue in coming months, with spending overall flat in July. In the near- term, the largest declines in construction spending should be in single family residential construction, in line with falling housing starts and permits of single- family homes. There has been some recent strength in multifamily housing starts, suggesting multifamily construction spending may increase some in coming months. Public construction spending will likely remain modest.

One of the most important details of construction spending data over the coming quarters however will be nonresidential private spending, particularly on structures like manufacturing facilities and data centers. A key question in recent months has been around the ability of capital expenditures and investment to support overall economic activity. This could be a result of tariffs causing businesses to reshore production, with various announcements by firms of substantial US investment plans, or a continued boost from Al- related investment.

Construction spending details may offer an early insight into the strength of both these dynamics. Construction of data centers has picked up in recent years and will likely continue to rise but is not nearly as substantial as spending on construction of manufacturing facilities, which has been trending gradually lower recently (although it would likely be too soon to see the effects of reshoring to increase manufacturing capacity). For now we are inclined to think this gradually falling trend may continue, as a boost to manufacturing from fiscal measures like the CHIPS act fades and tariffs weigh on real activity broadly.

S&P Manufacturing PMI has been stronger than ISM Manufacturing this year and was stronger than expected in August. ISM Manufacturing has been on a downtrend and generally in contraction. Hard manufacturing data have been mixed with industrial production which measures real activity moving mainly sideways in recent months while core durable goods orders (measures nominal orders) have been growing. Regional manufacturing surveys have also been somewhat mixed. We expect ISM Manufacturing to rebound to 49.0 from 48.0 in August, pointing to little change in manufacturing activity. The employment index could rebound somewhat but still remain in contraction, in line with our expectation for a continued decline in manufacturing payrolls. The employment index in ISM Manufacturing has aligned somewhat better with manufacturing payrolls than S&P PMI manufacturing.
Figure 20. ISM Manufacturing should remain in contraction
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, ISM
Figure 21. ISM Services has been weaker than S&P Services PMI
\((\widehat{\Xi})\) 2025 Citigroup Inc. No redistribution without Citigroup's written permission. Source: Citi Research, ISM

Similar to manufacturing, ISM Services has been weaker relative to S&P Services PMI but both have generally been in expansion in recent months. Services consumption has been growing at a slower pace this year in GDP data pointing to slowing in underlying growth. We expect further slowing into the second half of the year as the labor market weakens further. We expect some modest improvement in ISM Services in August to 51.2 from 50.1, within the range of this year and pointing to a modest expansion in services activity. Key details like the employment index could remain subdued with labor demand generally slowing.
Initial Jobless Claims - Citi: 229k, median: NA, prior: 229k Continuing Claims - Citi: 1962k, median: NA, prior: 1952k

Initial jobless claims fell modestly in this week's report close to expectations. Generally initial jobless claims remain within the range of recent years and are at low levels. This is consistent with low layoffs. For the week of August 30th we expect initial claims to be unchanged at 229k.

Continuing jobless claims were lower than expected this week but the they continue to be generally at higher levels than the start of the year and recent years as hiring has slowed. For the week of August 30th we expect a rebound to 1962k from 1954k, staying close to the recent range.
Figure 22. FOMC ranked from hawkish to dovish

The Firm's research department has received assistance from the subject company(ies) referred to in this Product including, but not limited to, discussions with management of the subject company(ies). Firm policy prohibits research analysts from sending draft research to subject companies. However, it should be presumed that the author of the Product has had discussions with the subject company to ensure factual accuracy prior to publication. Statements and views concerning ESG (environmental, social, governance) factors are typically based upon public statements made by the affected company or other public news, which the author may not have independently verified. ESG factors are one consideration that investors may choose to examine when making investment decisions. All opinions, projections and estimates constitute the judgment of the author as of the date of the Product and these, plus any other information contained in the Product, are subject to change without notice. Notwithstanding other departments within the Firm advising the companies discussed in this Product, information obtained in such role is not used in the preparation of the Product.
